did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.unittitle: Chesapeake, City of/Norfolk County (Va.) Processioner's Records, 1853-1854
did.origination: Chesapeake, City of/Norfolk County (Va.) Circuit Court

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Chesapeake, City of/Norfolk County (Va.) Processioner's Records, 1853-1854. Local government records collection, Chesapeake, City of/Norfolk County Court Records. The Library of Virginia, Richmond, Virginia 23219.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: These items came to the Library of Virginia in a transfer of court papers from the City of Chesapeake.

bioghist.head: Historical Information
bioghist.p: City of Chesapeake, which is named for the Chesapeake Bay, comprises the former Norfolk County and the former city of South Norfolk. It was formed by court order on 1 January 1963 with the merger of the county and city, both of which thereby became extinct.

Norfolk County was created from Elizabeth City County in 1636 or 1637 and named by direction of King Charles I. The earliest court record is dated 15 May 1637. Early records refer to the county as Norfolk, Lower Norfolk, or New Norfolk, as well as the lower county of New Norfolk and the lower county of Norfolk. By January 1640 the county had been divided into Upper Norfolk County and Lower Norfolk County, and in 1691 Lower Norfolk County was divided into Norfolk County and Princess Anne County.

Two freeholders were appointed on order of the county court to procession or review the bounds of farms or tracts of land in each precinct in order to renew or replace old landmarks. This was originally a function of the church vestry, but was continued by the court after disestablishment. Persons who walked the boundaries were called processioners.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Chesapeake, City of/Norfolk County (Va.) Processioner's Records, 1853-1854 typically record an area of land processioned with geographical landmarks, roads, property lines noted, the names of the persons present, the date(s) when the processioning occurred, the names of the processioners, and the date that the return was recorded by the local court.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Additional Chesapeake, City of/Norfolk County records can be found on microfilm at The Library of Virginia web site. Consult "A Guide to Virginia County and City Records on Microfilm."
